Questions.Question: What is the normal heart rate?
Questions.Hint: The normal heart rate is the number of times the heart beats per minute and is influenced by age, activity level, and fitness level.
Questions.Answer: The normal heart rate is between 60 and 100 beats per minute (bpm).

Questions.Question: What is the difference between a heart murmur and a heart bruit?
Questions.Hint: A murmur is a sound made by turbulence in blood flow, whereas a bruit is a sound made by turbulence in air flow.
Questions.Answer: A heart murmur is a sound made by turbulent blood flow in the heart or major blood vessels, while a heart bruit is a sound made by turbulent air flow in the heart or major blood vessels.

Questions.Question: What is the clinical significance of a third heart sound?
Questions.Hint: A third heart sound is often a sign of congestive heart failure.
Questions.Answer: A third heart sound (S3) is a low-pitched sound that occurs in early diastole. It is often a sign of congestive heart failure.

Questions.Question: What is the cause of a pericardial friction rub?
Questions.Hint: A pericardial friction rub is caused by inflammation or scarring of the pericardium.
Questions.Answer: A pericardial friction rub is a scratching or grating sound that occurs during systole and diastole. It is caused by inflammation or scarring of the pericardium.

Questions.Question: What is the difference between a systolic and a diastolic murmur?
Questions.Hint: A systolic murmur occurs during systole, while a diastolic murmur occurs during diastole.
Questions.Answer: A systolic murmur occurs during systole (when the heart is contracting) and is typically caused by blood flowing through a narrowed valve or a hole in the heart. A diastolic murmur occurs during diastole (when the heart is relaxing) and is typically caused by blood flowing back through a leaky valve.

Questions.Question: What is the clinical significance of a pansystolic murmur?
Questions.Hint: A pansystolic murmur is often a sign of mitral regurgitation.
Questions.Answer: A pansystolic murmur is a murmur that occurs throughout systole and is often a sign of mitral regurgitation (a condition in which the mitral valve leaks).

Questions.Question: What is the cause of a midsystolic click?
Questions.Hint: A midsystolic click is often caused by mitral valve prolapse.
Questions.Answer: A midsystolic click is a high-pitched sound that occurs in mid-systole and is often caused by mitral valve prolapse (a condition in which the mitral valve leaflets bulge into the left atrium during systole).

Questions.Question: What is the clinical significance of an opening snap?
Questions.Hint: An opening snap is often a sign of mitral stenosis.
Questions.Answer: An opening snap is a high-pitched sound that occurs at the beginning of diastole and is often a sign of mitral stenosis (a condition in which the mitral valve is narrowed).

Questions.Question: What is the cause of a Carey Coombs murmur?
Questions.Hint: A Carey Coombs murmur is a diastolic murmur that is caused by the flow of blood across an incompetent aortic valve.
Questions.Answer: A Carey Coombs murmur is a diastolic murmur that is heard best along the left sternal border and is caused by the flow of blood across an incompetent aortic valve.

Questions.Question: What is the clinical significance of a Graham Steell murmur?
Questions.Hint: A Graham Steell murmur is a diastolic murmur that is caused by the flow of blood across an incompetent pulmonary valve.
Questions.Answer: A Graham Steell murmur is a diastolic murmur that is heard best along the left sternal border and is caused by the flow of blood across an incompetent pulmonic valve.
